location: Padua. A room in BAPTISTAS house.

lines.text: Enter KATHARINA and BIANCA

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Good sister, wrong me not, nor wrong yourself, To make a bondmaid and a slave of me That I disdain: but for these other gawds, Unbind my hands, Ill pull them off myself, Yea, all my raiment, to my petticoat Or what you will command me will I do, So well I know my duty to my elders.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Of all thy suitors, here I charge thee, tell Whom thou lovest best: see thou dissemble not.

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Believe me, sister, of all the men alive I never yet beheld that special face Which I could fancy more than any other.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Minion, thou liest. Ist not Hortensio

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: If you affect him, sister, here I swear Ill plead for you myself, but you shall have him.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: O then, belike, you fancy riches more: You will have Gremio to keep you fair.

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Is it for him you do envy me so Nay then you jest, and now I well perceive You have but jested with me all this while: I prithee, sister Kate, untie my hands.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: If that be jest, then all the rest was so.
Strikes her
Enter BAPTISTA

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Why, how now, dame! whence grows this insolence Bianca, stand aside. Poor girl! she weeps. Go ply thy needle meddle not with her. For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit, Why dost thou wrong her that did neer wrong thee When did she cross thee with a bitter word

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Her silence flouts me, and Ill be revenged.
Flies after BIANCA

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: What, in my sight Bianca, get thee in.
Exit BIANCA

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: What, will you not suffer me Nay, now I see She is your treasure, she must have a husband I must dance barefoot on her wedding day And for your love to her lead apes in hell. Talk not to me: I will go sit and weep Till I can find occasion of revenge.
Exit

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I But who comes here Enter GREMIO, LUCENTIO in the habit of a mean man  PETRUCHIO, with HORTENSIO as a musician and TRANIO, with BIONDELLO bearing a lute and books

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Good morrow, neighbour Baptista.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Good morrow, neighbour Gremio. God save you, gentlemen!

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: And you, good sir! Pray, have you not a daughter Calld Katharina, fair and virtuous

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: I have a daughter, sir, called Katharina.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: You are too blunt: go to it orderly.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: You wrong me, Signior Gremio: give me leave. I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, That, hearing of her beauty and her wit, Her affability and bashful modesty, Her wondrous qualities and mild behavior, Am bold to show myself a forward guest Within your house, to make mine eye the witness Of that report which I so oft have heard. And, for an entrance to my entertainment, I do present you with a man of mine, Cunning in music and the mathematics, To instruct her fully in those sciences, Whereof I know she is not ignorant: Accept of him, or else you do me wrong: His name is Licio, born in Mantua.
Presenting HORTENSIO

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Youre welcome, sir and he, for your good sake. But for my daughter Katharina, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Mistake me not I speak but as I find. Whence are you, sir what may I call your name

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Petruchio is my name Antonios son, A man well known throughout all Italy.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: I know him well: you are welcome for his sake.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Saving your tale, Petruchio, I pray, Let us, that are poor petitioners, speak too: Baccare! you are marvellous forward.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: O, pardon me, Signior Gremio I would fain be doing.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: I doubt it not, sir but you will curse your wooing. Neighbour, this is a gift very grateful, I am sure of it. To express the like kindness, myself, that have been more kindly beholding to you than any, freely give unto you this young scholar, that hath been long studying at Rheims as cunning in Greek, Latin, and other languages, as the other in music and mathematics: his name is Cambio pray, accept his service.
Presenting LUCENTIO

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio. Welcome, good Cambio. But, gentle sir, methinks you walk like a stranger: may I be so bold to know the cause of your coming
To TRANIO

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Pardon me, sir, the boldness is mine own, That, being a stranger in this city here, Do make myself a suitor to your daughter, Unto Bianca, fair and virtuous. Nor is your firm resolve unknown to me, In the preferment of the eldest sister. This liberty is all that I request, That, upon knowledge of my parentage, I may have welcome mongst the rest that woo And free access and favour as the rest: And, toward the education of your daughters, I here bestow a simple instrument, And this small packet of Greek and Latin books: If you accept them, then their worth is great.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Lucentio is your name of whence, I pray

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Of Pisa, sir son to Vincentio.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: A mighty man of Pisa by report I know him well: you are very welcome, sir, Take you the lute, and you the set of books You shall go see your pupils presently. Holla, within! Sirrah, lead these gentlemen To my daughters and tell them both, These are their tutors: bid them use them well. We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner. You are passing welcome, And so I pray you all to think yourselves.
Enter a Servant
Exit Servant, with LUCENTIO and HORTENSIO, BIONDELLO following

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo. You knew my father well, and in him me, Left solely heir to all his lands and goods, Which I have betterd rather than decreased: Then tell me, if I get your daughters love, What dowry shall I have with her to wife

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: After my death the one half of my lands, And in possession twenty thousand crowns.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: And, for that dowry, Ill assure her of Her widowhood, be it that she survive me, In all my lands and leases whatsoever: Let specialties be therefore drawn between us, That covenants may be kept on either hand.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Ay, when the special thing is well obtaind, That is, her love for that is all in all.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, that is nothing: for I tell you, father, I am as peremptory as she proudminded And where two raging fires meet together They do consume the thing that feeds their fury: Though little fire grows great with little wind, Yet extreme gusts will blow out fire and all: So I to her and so she yields to me For I am rough and woo not like a babe.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Well mayst thou woo, and happy be thy speed! But be thou armd for some unhappy words.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Ay, to the proof as mountains are for winds, That shake not, though they blow perpetually.
Reenter HORTENSIO, with his head broke

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: How now, my friend! why dost thou look so pale

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: What, will my daughter prove a good musician

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: I think shell sooner prove a soldier Iron may hold with her, but never lutes.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Why, then thou canst not break her to the lute

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Why, no for she hath broke the lute to me. I did but tell her she mistook her frets, And bowd her hand to teach her fingering When, with a most impatient devilish spirit, Frets, call you these quoth she Ill fume with them: And, with that word, she struck me on the head, And through the instrument my pate made way And there I stood amazed for a while, As on a pillory, looking through the lute While she did call me rascal fiddler And twangling Jack with twenty such vile terms, As had she studied to misuse me so.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Now, by the world, it is a lusty wench I love her ten times more than eer I did: O, how I long to have some chat with her!

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Well, go with me and be not so discomfited: Proceed in practise with my younger daughter Shes apt to learn and thankful for good turns. Signior Petruchio, will you go with us, Or shall I send my daughter Kate to you

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: I pray you do. I will attend her here, And woo her with some spirit when she comes. Say that she rail why then Ill tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale: Say that she frown, Ill say she looks as clear As morning roses newly washd with dew: Say she be mute and will not speak a word Then Ill commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence: If she do bid me pack, Ill give her thanks, As though she bid me stay by her a week: If she deny to wed, Ill crave the day When I shall ask the banns and when be married. But here she comes and now, Petruchio, speak. Good morrow, Kate for thats your name, I hear.
Exeunt all but PETRUCHIO
Enter KATHARINA

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Well have you heard, but something hard of hearing: They call me Katharina that do talk of me.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: You lie, in faith for you are calld plain Kate, And bonny Kate and sometimes Kate the curst But Kate, the prettiest Kate in Christendom Kate of Kate Hall, my superdainty Kate, For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate, Take this of me, Kate of my consolation Hearing thy mildness praised in every town, Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded, Yet not so deeply as to thee belongs, Myself am moved to woo thee for my wife.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Moved! in good time: let him that moved you hither Remove you hence: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, whats a moveable

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: A joindstool.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Women are made to bear, and so are you.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: No such jade as you, if me you mean.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Alas! good Kate, I will not burden thee For, knowing thee to be but young and light

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Too light for such a swain as you to catch And yet as heavy as my weight should be.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Should be! shouldbuzz!

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Well taen, and like a buzzard.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: O slowwingd turtle! shall a buzzard take thee

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Ay, for a turtle, as he takes a buzzard.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Come, come, you wasp i faith, you are too angry.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: If I be waspish, best beware my sting.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: My remedy is then, to pluck it out.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Ay, if the fool could find it where it lies,

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Who knows not where a wasp does wear his sting In his tail.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: In his tongue.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Whose tongue

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Yours, if you talk of tails: and so farewell.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: What, with my tongue in your tail nay, come again, Good Kate I am a gentleman.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: That Ill try.
She strikes him

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: I swear Ill cuff you, if you strike again.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: So may you lose your arms: If you strike me, you are no gentleman And if no gentleman, why then no arms.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A herald, Kate O, put me in thy books!

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: What is your crest a coxcomb

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A combless cock, so Kate will be my hen.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: No cock of mine you crow too like a craven.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Nay, come, Kate, come you must not look so sour.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: It is my fashion, when I see a crab.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, heres no crab and therefore look not sour.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: There is, there is.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Then show it me.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Had I a glass, I would.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: What, you mean my face

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Well aimd of such a young one.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Now, by Saint George, I am too young for you.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Yet you are witherd.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Tis with cares.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I care not.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Nay, hear you, Kate: in sooth you scape not so.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: I chafe you, if I tarry: let me go.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: No, not a whit: I find you passing gentle. Twas told me you were rough and coy and sullen, And now I find report a very liar For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous, But slow in speech, yet sweet as springtime flowers: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip, as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk, But thou with mildness entertainst thy wooers, With gentle conference, soft and affable. Why does the world report that Kate doth limp O slanderous world! Kate like the hazeltwig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts and sweeter than the kernels. O, let me see thee walk: thou dost not halt.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Go, fool, and whom thou keepst command.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Did ever Dian so become a grove As Kate this chamber with her princely gait O, be thou Dian, and let her be Kate And then let Kate be chaste and Dian sportful!

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Where did you study all this goodly speech

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: It is extempore, from my motherwit.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: A witty mother! witless else her son.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Am I not wise

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Yes keep you warm.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Marry, so I mean, sweet Katharina, in thy bed: And therefore, setting all this chat aside, Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented That you shall be my wife your dowry greed on And, Will you, nill you, I will marry you. Now, Kate, I am a husband for your turn For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty, Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well, Thou must be married to no man but me For I am he am born to tame you Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates. Here comes your father: never make denial I must and will have Katharina to my wife.
Reenter BAPTISTA, GREMIO, and TRANIO

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: How but well, sir how but well It were impossible I should speed amiss.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Why, how now, daughter Katharina! in your dumps

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Call you me daughter now, I promise you You have showd a tender fatherly regard, To wish me wed to one half lunatic A madcup ruffian and a swearing Jack, That thinks with oaths to face the matter out.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Father, tis thus: yourself and all the world, That talkd of her, have talkd amiss of her: If she be curst, it is for policy, For shes not froward, but modest as the dove She is not hot, but temperate as the morn For patience she will prove a second Grissel, And Roman Lucrece for her chastity: And to conclude, we have greed so well together, That upon Sunday is the weddingday.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Ill see thee hangd on Sunday first.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Hark, Petruchio she says shell see thee hangd first.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Is this your speeding nay, then, good night our part!

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Be patient, gentlemen I choose her for myself: If she and I be pleased, whats that to you Tis bargaind twixt us twain, being alone, That she shall still be curst in company. I tell you, tis incredible to believe How much she loves me: O, the kindest Kate! She hung about my neck and kiss on kiss She vied so fast, protesting oath on oath, That in a twink she won me to her love. O, you are novices! tis a world to see, How tame, when men and women are alone, A meacock wretch can make the curstest shrew. Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice, To buy apparel gainst the weddingday. Provide the feast, father, and bid the guests I will be sure my Katharina shall be fine.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: I know not what to say: but give me your hands God send you joy, Petruchio! tis a match.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Amen, say we: we will be witnesses.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu I will to Venice Sunday comes apace: We will have rings and things and fine array And kiss me, Kate, we will be married oSunday.
Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA severally

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Was ever match clappd up so suddenly

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchants part, And venture madly on a desperate mart.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Twas a commodity lay fretting by you: Twill bring you gain, or perish on the seas.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: The gain I seek is, quiet in the match.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch. But now, Baptists, to your younger daughter: Now is the day we long have looked for: I am your neighbour, and was suitor first.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: And I am one that love Bianca more Than words can witness, or your thoughts can guess.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Youngling, thou canst not love so dear as I.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Graybeard, thy love doth freeze.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: But thine doth fry. Skipper, stand back: tis age that nourisheth.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: But youth in ladies eyes that flourisheth.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife: Tis deeds must win the prize and he of both That can assure my daughter greatest dower Shall have my Biancas love. Say, Signior Gremio, What can you assure her

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: First, as you know, my house within the city Is richly furnished with plate and gold Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands My hangings all of Tyrian tapestry In ivory coffers I have stuffd my crowns In cypress chests my arras counterpoints, Costly apparel, tents, and canopies, Fine linen, Turkey cushions bossd with pearl, Valance of Venice gold in needlework, Pewter and brass and all things that belong To house or housekeeping: then, at my farm I have a hundred milchkine to the pail, Sixscore fat oxen standing in my stalls, And all things answerable to this portion. Myself am struck in years, I must confess And if I die tomorrow, this is hers, If whilst I live she will be only mine.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: That only came well in. Sir, list to me: I am my fathers heir and only son: If I may have your daughter to my wife, Ill leave her houses three or four as good, Within rich Pisa walls, as any one Old Signior Gremio has in Padua Besides two thousand ducats by the year Of fruitful land, all which shall be her jointure. What, have I pinchd you, Signior Gremio

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Two thousand ducats by the year of land! My land amounts not to so much in all: That she shall have besides an argosy That now is lying in Marseilles road. What, have I choked you with an argosy

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Gremio, tis known my father hath no less Than three great argosies besides two galliases, And twelve tight galleys: these I will assure her, And twice as much, whateer thou offerst next.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Nay, I have offerd all, I have no more And she can have no more than all I have: If you like me, she shall have me and mine.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Why, then the maid is mine from all the world, By your firm promise: Gremio is outvied.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: I must confess your offer is the best And, let your father make her the assurance, She is your own else, you must pardon me, if you should die before him, wheres her dower

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: Thats but a cavil: he is old, I young.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: And may not young men die, as well as old

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Well, gentlemen, I am thus resolved: on Sunday next you know My daughter Katharina is to be married: Now, on the Sunday following, shall Bianca Be bride to you, if you this assurance If not, Signior Gremio: And so, I take my leave, and thank you both.

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Adieu, good neighbour. Now I fear thee not: Sirrah young gamester, your father were a fool To give thee all, and in his waning age Set foot under thy table: tut, a toy! An old Italian fox is not so kind, my boy.
Exit BAPTISTA
Exit

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: A vengeance on your crafty witherd hide! Yet I have faced it with a card of ten. Tis in my head to do my master good: I see no reason but supposed Lucentio Must get a father, calld supposed Vincentio And thats a wonder: fathers commonly Do get their children but in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
Exit
